      • Methods inherited from interface javax0.wtf.HasDefinition

        getDefinition

    • Method Detail

      • getStep

        Step getStep()
        Get the step that this action is executed from. Every action starts from a step in the workflow and transfers the workflow into other (or the same) step or steps. This method returns the step from which the action can be executed from.
        Returns:
        the step

      • getParameters

        java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> getParameters()
        Get the parameter map that belongs to the action.

        Actions are defined in a workflow and an action can be performed starting from many steps. The definition of the work flow may define parameters separately at each such use.

        The implementation SimpleWorkflow allows actions to have parameters that are generic for all steps, no matter where the action is used. In that case the returned map will return the merged set.

        Returns:
        the parameter Map

      • getResult

        Result getResult(java.lang.String name)
        Get a result based on its name that belongs to the action.
        Parameters:
        name - of the action
        Returns:
        the result object
        Throws:
        InvalidResultException - if there is no result for the action with the given name.

      • getResults

        Result[] getResults()
        Returns:
        all the possible results for this action that are defined in the workflow definition.

      • perform

        default Step[] perform()
                throws ValidatorFailedException,
                       java.lang.ClassNotFoundException,
                       java.lang.InstantiationException,
                       java.lang.IllegalAccessException
        Execute the pre-function, validator and post-function for the specific action and moves the workflow to the target step or target steps in case the action with the result returned by the post function is a split action.

        This method is called when an action can be performed automatically without user input.

        The method should also alter the steps of the work flow object, so the next call to getSteps() should return the steps.

        Returns:
        the step or steps that the work flow is after performing the action. This replaces the step 'step' in the argument in the array of steps which is returned by getSteps().
        Throws:
        ValidatorFailedException
        java.lang.ClassNotFoundException
        java.lang.InstantiationException
        java.lang.IllegalAccessException

      • performPre

        java.lang.Object performPre()
                     throws java.lang.ClassNotFoundException,
                            java.lang.InstantiationException,
                            java.lang.IllegalAccessException
        Execute the pre-function of the action.

        This method is called when the action should be performed in two phases. The first phase is the pre-function and gathering user input. The second phase is to execute the validator and the post-function.

        When the action is performed in two phase the pre-function returns a transientState object that the post function and the validator may use to perform their methods.

        Returns:
        the transient state object the pre-function creates
        Throws:
        java.lang.ClassNotFoundException
        java.lang.InstantiationException
        java.lang.IllegalAccessException

      • performPost

        Step[] performPost(java.lang.Object transientObject,
                   java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> userInput)
            throws ValidatorFailedException,
                   java.lang.ClassNotFoundException,
                   java.lang.InstantiationException,
                   java.lang.IllegalAccessException
        Execute the post-function of the action.

        This method is called when the action should be performed in two phases as described in the documentation of the method {

        Parameters:
        transientObject - the transient state object returned by the pre-function
        userInput - the user-input that was gathered after calling pre-function
        Returns:
        the steps to which the action transfers from the old step. (Not all the steps the work flow is in after the action, only the ones that replace the step we transit from.) It returns null if the action postFunction returned null. In that case the steps the work flow is in remain the same.
        Throws:
        ValidatorFailedException - #performPre(StepDefinition step, ActionDefinition action).

        The method should also alter the steps of the work flow object, so the next call to getSteps() should return the steps that the work flow is after the execution of the action.

        java.lang.ClassNotFoundException
        java.lang.InstantiationException
        java.lang.IllegalAccessException

      • join

        void join(Step[] steps)
        Join the steps listed in the argument list into this action.

        This method can be used to implement a join programmatically. The post function may call this method to list all the steps that have to be joined to the actual flow. Joining means that the workflow will not be in the steps listed in the argument, but only in the steps in which the actual action performing leads to.

        More precisely the the method join(Step[] steps) will remove the listed steps from the set of steps that the workflow is in currently. Other steps that are not removed will still belong to the set. The new set of steps will be the ones that the currently executing action leads to and the steps that were not joined.

        The actual implementation should be sloppy in the sense that the caller may specify steps that the workflow is not currently in.

        This is a complimentary method that can be implemented using only the interface methods, and the implementation in the package com.verhas.workflow.simple is one that does not depend on the actual implementation details.

        Parameters:
        steps - the steps to join.

      • join

        void join(java.lang.String[] steps)
        Join the steps listed in the argument list into this action. The steps are listed by their names and not the actual steps. For more explanation {
        Parameters:
        steps - the names of the steps that are to be joined. join(Step[] steps).
